postBySlug.html:
Uml Diagram Shapes

Uml Class Diagram Shapes

Class diagram is used to represent the static view of an application. The class diagrams are widely used in the modelling of object oriented systems because they are the only UML diagrams which can be mapped directly with object-oriented languages. Diagram supports to generate the class diagram shapes from business logic.

The UML class diagram shapes are explained as follows.

Class

  • A class describes a set of objects that shares the same specifications of features, constraints, and semantics. To define a class object, you should define the classifier as Class.

  • Also, define the Name, Attributes, and Methods of the class using the class property of node.

  • The attribute’s Name, Type, and Scope properties allow you to define the name, data type, and visibility of the attribute.

  • The method’s Name, Parameters, Type, and Scope properties allow you to define the name, parameter, return type, and visibility of the methods.

  • The method parameters object properties allow you to define the name and type of the parameter.

  • The following code example illustrates how to create a class.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramNodes>
        <DiagramNode Id="Patient" Height="40" Width="105" OffsetX="300" OffsetY="85">
            @* Sets type of shape and classifier *@
            <DiagramUmlClassifierShape Type="@Syncfusion.EJ2.Blazor.Diagrams.Shapes.UmlClassifier" Classifier="@ClassifierShape.Class">
                @* Sets the class object with Name of a class header *@
                <DiagramUmlClass Name="Patient">
                    @* Sets the collection of attributes *@
                    <DiagramUmlClassAttributes >
                        <DiagramUmlClassAttribute Name="accepted" Type="Date"></DiagramUmlClassAttribute>
                    </DiagramUmlClassAttributes>
                    @* Sets the collection of methods *@
                    <DiagramUmlClassMethods >
                        @* sets the arguments for methods *@
                        <DiagramUmlClassMethod Name="GetHistory" Type="GetHistory"></DiagramUmlClassMethod>
                    </DiagramUmlClassMethods>
                </DiagramUmlClass>
            </DiagramUmlClassifierShape>
        </DiagramNode>
    </DiagramNodes>
</EjsDiagram>

Interface

  • An Interface is a kind of classifier that represents a declaration of a set of coherent public features and obligations. To create an interface, define the classifier property as Interface.

  • Also, define the Name, Attributes, and Methods of the interface using the interface property of the node.

  • The attribute’s name, type, and scope properties allow you to define the name, data type, and visibility of the attribute.

  • The method’s name, parameter, type, and scope properties allow you to define the name, parameter, return type, and visibility of the methods.

  • The method parameter object properties of name and type allows you to define the name and type of the parameter.

  • The following code example illustrates how to create an interface.

Enumeration

  • To define an enumeration, define the classifier property of node as Enumeration. Also, define the name and members of the enumeration using the enumeration property of the node.

  • You can set a name for the enumeration members collection using the name property of members collection.

  • The following code example illustrates how to create an enumeration.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramNodes>
        <DiagramNode Id="Patient" Height="40" Width="105" OffsetX="300" OffsetY="85">
            @* Sets type of shape and classifier *@
            <DiagramUmlClassifierShape Type="@Syncfusion.EJ2.Blazor.Diagrams.Shapes.UmlClassifier" Classifier="@ClassifierShape.Enumeration">
                @* Sets the enumeration object with Name of a class header *@
                <DiagramUmlEnumeration Name="AccountType">
                    @* sets the Enumeration Members *@
                    <DiagramUmlEnumerationMembers>
                        <DiagramUmlEnumerationMember Name="Checking Account"></DiagramUmlEnumerationMember>
                        <DiagramUmlEnumerationMember Name="Savings Account"></DiagramUmlEnumerationMember>
                        <DiagramUmlEnumerationMember Name="Credit Account"></DiagramUmlEnumerationMember>
                    </DiagramUmlEnumerationMembers>
                </DiagramUmlEnumeration>
            </DiagramUmlClassifierShape>
        </DiagramNode>
    </DiagramNodes>
</EjsDiagram>

Connector shapes

  • The connector shape property defines the role or meaning of the connector.

  • The different types of connector shapes are BPMN, UmlClassifier and UmlActivity and can render these shapes by setting the connector shape type property.

  • The type of flow shapes in a BPMN process are sequence, association, and message.

Relationships

  • A relationship is a general term covering the specific types of logical connections found on class diagrams.

  • The list of relationships are demonstrated as follows.

Shape Image
Association
Aggregation
Composition
Inheritance
Dependency

Association

Association is basically a set of links that connects elements of an UML model. The type of association are as follows.

1. Directional
2. BiDirectional

The association property allows you to define the type of association. The default value of association is “Directional”. The following code example illustrates how to create an association.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnectors>
            <DiagramConnector Id="connector1">
                @* Sets the source and target points for the connector *@
                <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="100"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
                <ConnectorTargetPoint X="300" Y="200"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
                @* Sets the type of the relationships as association *@
                <DiagramRelationShip Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlClassifier" Relationship="@ClassifierShape.Association" AssociationType="@AssociationFlow.BiDirectional"></DiagramRelationShip>
            </DiagramConnector>
        </DiagramConnectors>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

Aggregation

Aggregation is a binary association between a property and one or more composite objects which group together a set of instances. Aggregation is decorated with a hollow diamond. To create an aggregation shape, define the relationship as “aggregation”.

The following code example illustrates how to create an aggregation.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnectors>
            <DiagramConnector Id="connector1">
            @* Sets the source and target points for the connector *@
                <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="100"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
                <ConnectorTargetPoint X="300" Y="200"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
                    @*  Sets the type of the relationships as Aggregation *@
                <DiagramRelationShip Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlClassifier" Relationship="@ClassifierShape.Aggregation" AssociationType="@AssociationFlow.BiDirectional"></DiagramRelationShip>
            </DiagramConnector>
        </DiagramConnectors>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

Composition

Composition is a “strong” form of “aggregation”. Composition is decorated with a black diamond. To create a composition shape, define the relationship property of connector as “composition”.

The following code example illustrates how to create a composition.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnectors>
            <DiagramConnector Id="connector1">
                <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="100"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
                <ConnectorTargetPoint X="300" Y="200"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
                @* Sets the type of the relationships as Composition *@
                <DiagramRelationShip Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlClassifier" Relationship="@ClassifierShape.Composition" AssociationType="@AssociationFlow.BiDirectional"></DiagramRelationShip>
            </DiagramConnector>
        </DiagramConnectors>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

Dependency

Dependency is a directed relationship, which is used to show that some UML elements needs or depends on other model elements for specifications. Dependency is shown as dashed line with opened arrow. To create a dependency, define the relationship property of connector as “dependency”.

The following code example illustrates how to create an dependency.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnectors>
            <DiagramConnector Id="connector1">
                @* Sets the source and target points for the connector *@
                <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="100"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
                <ConnectorTargetPoint X="300" Y="200"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
                    @*  Sets the type of the relationships as Dependency *@
                <DiagramRelationShip Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlClassifier" Relationship="@ClassifierShape.Dependency" AssociationType="@AssociationFlow.BiDirectional"></DiagramRelationShip>
            </DiagramConnector>
        </DiagramConnectors>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

Inheritance

Inheritance is also called as “generalization”. Inheritance is a binary taxonomic directed relationship between a more general classifier (super class) and a more specific classifier (subclass). Inheritance is shown as a line with hollow triangle.

To create an inheritance, define the relationship as “inheritance”.

The following code example illustrates how to create an inheritance.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnectors>
            <DiagramConnector Id="connector1">
                @* Sets the source and target points for the connector *@
                <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="100"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
                <ConnectorTargetPoint X="300" Y="200"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
                @*  Sets the type of the relationships as Inheritance *@
                <DiagramRelationShip Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlClassifier" Relationship="@ClassifierShape.Inheritance" AssociationType="@AssociationFlow.BiDirectional"></DiagramRelationShip>
            </DiagramConnector>
        </DiagramConnectors>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

Multiplicity

Multiplicity is a definition of an inclusive interval of non-negative integers to specify the allowable number of instances of described element. The type of multiplicity are as follows.

1. OneToOne
2. ManyToOne
3. OneToMany
4. ManyToMany

  • By default the multiplicity will be considered as “OneToOne”.

  • The multiplicity property in UML allows you to specify large number of elements or some collection of elements.

  • The shape multiplicity’s source property is used to set the source label to connector and the target property is used to set the target label to connector.

  • To set an optionality or cardinality for the connector source label, use optional property.

  • The LowerBounds and UpperBounds could be natural constants or constant expressions evaluated to natural (non negative) number. Upper bound could be also specified as asterisk ‘*’ which denotes unlimited number of elements. Upper bound should be greater than or equal to the lower bound.

  • The following code example illustrates how to customize the multiplicity.

 <EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnector Id="connector1" Type="@Segments.Straight">
            @* Sets the source and target points for the connector *@
            <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="100"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
            <ConnectorTargetPoint X="300" Y="300"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
            @* sets the UmlClassifier shape connector *@
            <DiagramConnectorShape Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlClassifier">
                @*  Sets the type of the relationships as Dependency *@
                <DiagramRelationShip Relationship="@ClassifierShape.Dependency">
                    @* Sets the type of multiplicity *@
                    <DiagramClassifierMultiplicity Type="@Multiplicity.OneToMany">
                        @* Sets the source label *@
                        <SourceMultiplicityLabel>
                            @* Sets the optionality/cardinality for the connector and Specifies interval for number of instances of described element *@
                            <ConnectorsMultiplicityLabel Optional="true" LowerBounds="80" UpperBounds="67"></ConnectorsMultiplicityLabel>
                        </SourceMultiplicityLabel>
                        @* Sets the target label *@
                        <TargerMultiplicityLabel>
                            @* Sets the optionality/cardinality for the connector and Specifies interval for number of instances of described element *@
                            <ConnectorsMultiplicityLabel Optional="true" LowerBounds="78" UpperBounds="90"></ConnectorsMultiplicityLabel>
                        </TargerMultiplicityLabel>
                    </DiagramClassifierMultiplicity>
                </DiagramRelationShip>
            </DiagramConnectorShape>
        </DiagramConnector>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

UmlActivity diagram

Activity diagram is basically a flowchart to represent the flow from one activity to another. The activity can be described as an operation of the system.

The purpose of an activity diagram can be described as follows.

1. Draw the activity flow of a system.

2. Describe the sequence from one activity to another.

3. Describe the parallel, branched, and concurrent flow of the system.

To create a UmlActivity, define type as “UmlActivity” and the list of built-in shapes as demonstrated as follows and it should be set in the “shape” property.

Shape Image
Action
Decision
MergeNode
InitialNode
FinalNode
ForkNode
JoinNode
TimeEvent
AcceptingEvent
SendSignal
ReceiveSignal
StructuredNode
Note

The following code illustrates how to create a UmlActivity shapes.

 <EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramNodes>
        @* Initialize the activity shape *@
        <DiagramNode Id="UmlDiagram" Height="100" Width="100" OffsetX="200" OffsetY="200">
            @* Sets Type as UmlActivity and Shape as Action *@
            <DiagramUmlActivityShape Type="@Shapes.UmlActivity" Shape="@UmlActivityShapes.Action">
            </DiagramUmlActivityShape>
        </DiagramNode>
    </DiagramNodes>
</EjsDiagram>

UmlActivity connector

To create an UmlActivity connector, define the type as “UmlActivity” and flow as either “Exception” or “Control” or “Object”.

The following code illustrates how to create a UmlActivity connector.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramConnectors>
        @* Initialize the Diagram uml connector *@
        <DiagramConnector Id="connector1" Type="@Segments.Straight">
            @* Sets the source and target points for the connector *@
            <ConnectorSourcePoint X="100" Y="700"></ConnectorSourcePoint>
            <ConnectorTargetPoint X="200" Y="800"></ConnectorTargetPoint>
            @* sets the UmlClassifier shape connector *@
            <DiagramConnectorShape Type="@ConnectionShapes.UmlActivity" Flow="@UmlActivityFlows.Exception"></DiagramConnectorShape>
        </DiagramConnector>
    </DiagramConnectors>
</EjsDiagram>

Editing

You can edit the name, attributes, and methods of the class diagram shapes just double clicking, similar to editing a node annotation.

The following image illustrates how the text editor looks in an edit mode.

previous.html:
History List

Diagram tracks the history of actions that are performed after initializing the diagram and provides support to reverse and restore those changes.

Undo and redo

Diagram provides built-in support to track the changes that are made through interaction and through public APIs. The changes can be reverted or restored either through shortcut keys or through commands.

Undo/redo through shortcut keys

Undo/redo commands can be executed through shortcut keys. Shortcut key for undo is Ctrl+z and shortcut key for redo is Ctrl+y.

Undo/redo through public APIs

The client-side methods Undo and Redo help you to revert/restore the changes. The following code example illustrates how to undo/redo the changes through script.

<button onclick="@Undo">Undo</button><button onclick="@Redo">Redo</button>
<EjsDiagram id="diagram" ref="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
</EjsDiagram>
@functions{
    EjsDiagram diagram;
    public void Undo()
    {
        // Reverts the last action performed
        this.diagram.Undo();
    }
    public void Redo()
    {
        // Restores the last undone action
        this.diagram.Redo();
    }
}

When a change in the diagram is reverted or restored (undo/redo), the HistoryChange event gets triggered.

Group multiple changes

History list allows to revert or restore multiple changes through a single undo/redo command. For example, revert/restore the fill color change of multiple elements at a time.

The client-side method StartGroupAction is used to notify the diagram to start grouping the changes. The client-side method EndGroupAction is used to notify to stop grouping the changes. The following code illustrates how to undo/redo fillColor change of multiple elements at a time.

<button onclick="@Undo">Undo</button><button onclick="@Redo">Redo</button>
<EjsDiagram id="diagram" ref="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
</EjsDiagram>
@functions{
    EjsDiagram diagram;
    DiagramNode node1;

    //Makes the changes here...
    public void GroupAction()
    {
        this.diagram.StartGroupAction();
        //Ends grouping the changes
        this.diagram.EndGroupAction();
    }
    public void Undo()
    {
        // Reverts the last action performed
        this.diagram.Undo();
    }
    public void Redo()
    {
        // Restores the last undone action
        this.diagram.Redo();
    }
}

Track custom changes

Diagram provides options to track the changes that are made to custom properties. For example, in case of an employee relationship diagram, track the changes in the employee information. The HistoryList of the diagram enables you to track such changes. The following example illustrates how to track such custom property changes.

Before changing the employee information, save the existing information to history list by using the client-side method push of HistoryList. The history list CanLog method can be used which takes a history entry as argument and returns whether the specific entry can be added or not.

The following code example illustrates how to save the existing property values.

<EjsDiagram ID="diagram" @ref="diagram" Width="100%" Height="690px">
    <DiagramNodes>
        <DiagramNode Id="NewIdea" @ref ="node1" Height="100" Width="100" OffsetX="100" OffsetY="100">
            @*Customizes the appearance of the node*@
            <NodeShapeStyle Fill="#6BA5D7" StrokeColor="white"></NodeShapeStyle>
            <DiagramNodeAnnotations>
                <DiagramNodeAnnotation Content="node1">
                    @*Customizes the appearance of the annotations*@
                    <NodeAnnotationStyle Color="white" StrokeColor="None"></NodeAnnotationStyle>
                </DiagramNodeAnnotation>
            </DiagramNodeAnnotations>
            @*Customizes the appearance of the node shadow style*@
            <DiagramShadow Angle="50" Opacity="0.8" Distance="9"></DiagramShadow>
        </DiagramNode>
    </DiagramNodes>
</EjsDiagram>
@functions{
    EjsDiagram diagram;
    DiagramNode node1;
    public void TrackCustomActions()
    {
        //Creates a custom entry
        object entry = node1;
        // adds that to history list
        this.diagram.AddHistoryEntry(entry);
        this.diagram.DataBind();
    }
}

fields.header:
Contents
  • Undo and redo
  • Undoredo through shortcut keys
  • Undoredo through public APIs
  • Group multiple changes
  • Track custom changes
fields.seoContent: Undo Redo in ASP.NET Core Blazor [Preview] Diagram | Syncfusion Documentation

next.html:
Symbol Palette

The SymbolPalette displays a collection of palettes. The palette shows a set of nodes and connectors. It allows to drag and drop the nodes and connectors into the diagram.

Create symbol palette

The Width and Height properties of the symbol palette allows to define the size of the symbol palette.

 @* initialize Symbol palette *@
<EjsSymbolPalette id="palettes" Width="100%" Height="700px" SymbolHeight=60 SymbolWidth=60>
</EjsSymbolPalette>

Add palettes to SymbolPalette

A palette allows to display a group of related symbols and it textually annotates the group with its header. A Palettes can be added as a collection of symbol groups.

The collection of predefined symbols can be added in palettes using the Symbols property.

To initialize a palette, define a JSON object with the property Id that is unique ID is set to the palettes.

The following code example illustrates how to define a palette and how its added to symbol palette.

@* initialize Symbol palette *@
<EjsSymbolPalette ID="palettes" Width="100%" Height="700px" SymbolHeight=60 SymbolWidth=60>
    <SymbolPalettePalettes>
        <SymbolPalettePalette Id="flow" Expanded="true" Symbols="@flowShapes" IconCss="e-ddb-icons e-flow" Title="Flow Shapes">
        </SymbolPalettePalette>
        <SymbolPalettePalette Id="connectors" Expanded="true" Symbols="@connectors" IconCss="e-ddb-icons e-connector" Title="Connectors">
        </SymbolPalettePalette>
    </SymbolPalettePalettes>
</EjsSymbolPalette>

@functions{

    private List<object> segment1 { get; set; } = new List<object> {
        new { direction= "Top", type= "Orthogonal", length= 120 }
    };
    private List<object> segment2 { get; set; } = new List<object>{
        new  { direction= "Right", type= "Orthogonal", length= 100 }
    };
    //Initialize the flowshapes for the symbol palatte
    private List<DiagramNode> flowShapes { get; set; } = new List<DiagramNode> {
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Terminator" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
            Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Terminator }
        },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Process" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Process }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Decision" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Decision }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Document" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Document }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="PreDefinedProcess" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.PreDefinedProcess }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="PaperTap" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.PaperTap }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="DirectData" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.DirectData }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="SequentialData" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.SequentialData }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Sort" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Sort }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="MultiDocument" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.MultiDocument }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Collate" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Collate }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Or" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Or }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Extract" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Extract }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Merge" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Merge }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="OffPageReference" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.OffPageReference }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="SequentialAccessStorage" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.SequentialAccessStorage }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Annotation" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Annotation }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Annotation2" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Annotation2 }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Data" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Data }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Card" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Card }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Delay" , Shape = new DiagramFlowShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Flow,Shape=FlowShapes.Delay }
    },
    };
    //Initializes connector symbols for the symbol palette
    private List<DiagramConnector> connectors { get; set; } = new List<DiagramConnector>
    {
        new DiagramConnector(){Id="Link11" ,  Type=Segments.Orthogonal,SourcePoint= new DiagramPolygonPoints(){ X=0,Y=0 },TargetPoint = new DiagramPolygonPoints(){  X=60,Y=60},
          TargetDecorator= new ConnectorDecorator(){ Shape=DecoratorShapes.Arrow},Style= new DiagramsShapeStyle(){ StrokeWidth=1}
        },
        new DiagramConnector(){Id="link12" ,  Type=Segments.Orthogonal,SourcePoint= new DiagramPolygonPoints(){ X=0,Y=0 },TargetPoint = new DiagramPolygonPoints(){  X=60,Y=60},
         TargetDecorator= new ConnectorDecorator(){ Shape=DecoratorShapes.None},Style= new DiagramsShapeStyle(){ StrokeWidth=1}
        },
        new DiagramConnector(){Id="Link21" ,  Type=Segments.Straight,SourcePoint= new DiagramPolygonPoints(){ X=0,Y=0 },TargetPoint = new DiagramPolygonPoints(){  X=60,Y=60},
          TargetDecorator= new ConnectorDecorator(){ Shape=DecoratorShapes.Arrow},Style= new DiagramsShapeStyle(){ StrokeWidth=1}
        },
        new DiagramConnector(){Id="link22" ,  Type=Segments.Straight,SourcePoint= new DiagramPolygonPoints(){ X=0,Y=0 },TargetPoint = new DiagramPolygonPoints(){  X=60,Y=60},
          TargetDecorator= new ConnectorDecorator(){ Shape=DecoratorShapes.None},Style= new DiagramsShapeStyle(){ StrokeWidth=1}
        },
        new DiagramConnector(){Id="Link31" ,  Type=Segments.Bezier,SourcePoint= new DiagramPolygonPoints(){ X=0,Y=0 },TargetPoint = new DiagramPolygonPoints(){  X=60,Y=60},
          TargetDecorator= new ConnectorDecorator(){ Shape=DecoratorShapes.Arrow},Style= new DiagramsShapeStyle(){ StrokeWidth=1}
        },
        new DiagramConnector(){Id="link32" ,  Type=Segments.Bezier,SourcePoint= new DiagramPolygonPoints(){ X=0,Y=0 },TargetPoint = new DiagramPolygonPoints(){  X=60,Y=60},
          TargetDecorator= new ConnectorDecorator(){ Shape=DecoratorShapes.None},Style= new DiagramsShapeStyle(){ StrokeWidth=1}
        }
    };
}

Add/Remove symbols to palette at runtime

  • Symbols can be added to palette at runtime by using public method, AddPaletteItem.

  • Symbols can be removed from palette at runtime by using public method, RemovePaletteItem.

Customize the size of symbols

The size of the individual symbol can be customized. The SymbolWidth and SymbolHeight properties of node enables you to define the size of the symbols. The following code example illustrates how to change the size of a symbol.

@* initialize Symbol palette with customize symbol size*@
<EjsSymbolPalette ID="palettes" Width="100%" Height="700px" SymbolHeight=60 SymbolWidth=60>
    @* Sets the margin for the symbols *@
    <SymbolMargin Left="15" Bottom="15" Right="15" Top="15"></SymbolMargin>
    <SymbolPalettePalettes>
        <SymbolPalettePalette Id="flow" Expanded="true" Symbols="@BasicsShapes" IconCss="e-ddb-icons e-flow" Title="Flow Shapes">
        </SymbolPalettePalette>
    </SymbolPalettePalettes>
</EjsSymbolPalette>

@functions{
    private List<DiagramNode> BasicsShapes { get; set; } = new List<DiagramNode> {
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Rectangle" , Shape = new DiagramBasicShape(){
            Type =Shapes.Basic,Shape=BasicShapes.Rectangle }
        },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Ellipse" , Shape = new DiagramBasicShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Basic,Shape=BasicShapes.Ellipse }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Hexagon" , Shape = new DiagramBasicShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Basic,Shape=BasicShapes.Hexagon }
    },
    };
}

The SymbolMargin property is used to create the space around elements, outside of any defined borders.

Symbol preview

The symbol preview size of the palette items can be customized using SymbolPreview. The Width and Height properties of SymbolPalette enables you to define the preview size to all the symbol palette items. The Offset of the dragging helper relative to the mouse cursor.

The following code example illustrates how to change the preview size of a palette item.

@* initialize Symbol palette with customize symbol size*@
<EjsSymbolPalette ID="palettes" Width="100%" Height="700px" SymbolHeight=60 SymbolWidth=60>
    @* Sets the margin for the symbols *@
    <SymbolMargin Left="15" Bottom="15" Right="15" Top="15"></SymbolMargin>
    @* Sets the preview for the symbols in symbo palette *@
    <SymbolPreview Height="100" Width="100" OffsetX="0.5" OffsetY="0.5"></SymbolPreview>
    <SymbolPalettePalettes>
        <SymbolPalettePalette Id="flow" Expanded="true" Symbols="@BasicsShapes" IconCss="e-ddb-icons e-flow" Title="Flow Shapes">
        </SymbolPalettePalette>
    </SymbolPalettePalettes>
</EjsSymbolPalette>

@functions{
    private List<DiagramNode> BasicsShapes { get; set; } = new List<DiagramNode> {
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Rectangle" , Shape = new DiagramBasicShape(){
            Type =Shapes.Basic,Shape=BasicShapes.Rectangle }
        },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Ellipse" , Shape = new DiagramBasicShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Basic,Shape=BasicShapes.Ellipse }
    },
        new DiagramNode(){Id="Hexagon" , Shape = new DiagramBasicShape(){
        Type =Shapes.Basic,Shape=BasicShapes.Hexagon }
    },
    };
}

Palette interaction

Palette interaction notifies the element enter, leave, and dragging of the symbols into the diagram.

Escape Key function

The diagram provides support to cancel the node from symbol palette when the ESC key is pressed.

Clear Previous Selection

We have provided the new support to prevent “previous selection gets cleared when dragging a new symbol from the symbol palette and dropping it to the diagram”. The following image illustrate how to cancel the selection in previous object while we drop symbol from palette

DragEnter

[DragEnter][`idragentereventargs`](../api/diagram/iDragEnterEventArgs) notifies, when the element enter into the diagram from symbol palette.

DragLeave

[DragLeave][`idragleaveeventargs`](../api/diagram/iDragLeaveEventArgs) notifies, when the element leaves from the diagram.

DragOver

[DragOver][`idragovereventargs`](../api/diagram/iDragOverEventArgs) notifies, when an element drag over another diagram element.

See Also

  • How to add the symbol to the diagram
